misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that all variables used within a method, including loop control variables (a, b) and even unused placeholders (c), must be declared and initialized at the start of the program or method before they can be used in control structures.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables should ideally be declared in the narrowest scope possible (e.g., within the for-loop header). The student does not realize that 'for(int a = 1...)' both declares the variable and limits its scope to the loop, which is safer and more idiomatic than declaring all variables at the top of the method.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that a variable must be assigned an initial value during its declaration (a=1, b=1) even if it will be immediately re-assigned a new value in a loop header (for(a=1;...)) before its first use.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to understand the execution order of a for-loop, specifically that the initialization expression (the first part of the for-loop header) executes before any other part of the loop, overwriting any previously held value.
